Get permission to hold an event on council-owned parks, open spaces, and public land in Gloucester.

What you get

  • ✓ Permission to use council land for your event
  • ✓ Advice and guidance from the City Events Manager
  • ✓ Assessment by the City Events Group
  • ✓ Help with licensing and permissions
  • ✓ Site inspection if needed
  • ✓ Emergency contact support on event day

Types of events we support

Community events

Festivals, fetes, and celebrations

Sports events

Tournaments and competitions

Charity events

Fundraising and awareness events

Cultural events

Performances and shows

Music events

Concerts and outdoor music

Markets and fairs

Craft fairs and markets

Available venues

  • Gloucester Park
    Premier city park with 11 hectares of space. Includes cricket club, bowling club, skate park, and bandstand
  • Hillfield Gardens
    Community park suitable for smaller events
  • Barnwood Park & Arboretum
    Green space with varied facilities
  • Plock Court & Oxstalls Sports Park
    Sports facilities and outdoor space
  • City centre open spaces
    Various locations in the city centre

Check venue availability Contact the City Events team at city.events@gloucester.gov.uk or call 01452 396396

How to apply

  1. 1 Contact the City Events team
    Discuss your proposal and check venue availability
  2. 2 Complete Event Application Form
    Fill in all details about your event
  3. 3 Prepare supporting documents
    Risk assessment, site plan, and insurance certificate
  4. 4 Submit application
    Email all documents to city.events@gloucester.gov.uk
  5. 5 Application reviewed
    City Events Group will assess your application
  6. 6 Receive decision
    We will tell you if your event is approved
  7. 7 Sign land use agreement
    If approved, sign the agreement
  8. 8 Pay fees
    Pay any fees and deposit before your event
  9. 9 Get licensing if needed
    Apply for Temporary Event Notice if selling alcohol or having music
  10. 10 Pre-event site inspection
    If needed, we will visit the site with you
  11. 11 Hold your event
    Run your event safely
  12. 12 Clear the site
    Remove all equipment and waste, return site to original condition
  13. 13 Post-event debrief
    If needed, meet with us to discuss how it went

How far in advance to apply

Small events (up to 499 people)

Events with up to 499 people and no amplified or live music

Apply at least 3 months before your event

Medium events (500-2999 people)

Events with 500-2999 people or needing licensing

Apply 3-6 months before your event

Large events (3000+ people)

Events with 3000 or more people

Apply at least 6 months before your event

What you need to provide

1. Risk assessment

You must assess all risks at your event. This includes:

  • Hazards during the event
  • Setup and takedown activities
  • Site-specific risks (slopes, water, roads nearby)
  • Weather risks
  • Crowd management
  • Emergency evacuation
  • Fire safety
  • Electrical safety
  • Food safety (if serving food)
  • First aid provision
  • Safeguarding (especially for children's events)
  • Accessibility

2. Site plan

You must provide a plan showing:

  • Event layout and where activities will be
  • Stages, stalls, marquees, equipment
  • Emergency vehicle access points (at least 3 metres wide)
  • Entrances and exits for people
  • Emergency evacuation routes
  • First aid points
  • Fire safety equipment locations
  • Toilets (including accessible toilets)
  • Lost children point (if family event)
  • Alcohol sale areas (if selling alcohol)
  • Food vendor locations
  • Generator and power supply locations
  • Parking areas
  • Barriers and fencing

3. Insurance

You must have:

  • Public liability insurance – at least £5 million cover. This protects against claims for injury, damage or loss to members of the public
  • Employers liability insurance – at least £5 million cover if you have paid staff or volunteers. This is a legal requirement

4. Licensing (if needed)

Temporary Event Notice (TEN)

You need a TEN if you are:

  • Selling or supplying alcohol
  • Having live music, recorded music, or performances
  • Serving hot food or drink between 11pm and 5am

A TEN costs £21 and covers up to 499 people. Apply at least 10 working days before your event.

Premises Licence

You need a full premises licence if:

  • You have 500 or more people at any one time
  • Your event is longer than 7 days
  • You are having more than 15 events per year at the same location

Allow at least 3 months to apply for a premises licence.

Music licensing

If you have live or recorded music, you may need a licence from PRS for Music. Call 0800 068 4828.

Your responsibilities

Before the event

  • Apply 3-6 months in advance
  • Complete event application form
  • Provide risk assessment
  • Provide site plan
  • Get insurance (at least £5 million public liability)
  • Apply for TEN or premises licence if needed
  • Contact PRS for Music if you have music
  • Tell local residents if your event will cause noise or disruption
  • Arrange staff and marshals
  • Book toilets, first aid, and waste collection
  • Arrange electricity if needed

During the event

  • Supervise the event at all times
  • Keep emergency vehicle access clear (3 metres wide)
  • Manage crowds safely
  • Check site safety
  • Have emergency contact details available
  • Display your TEN if you have one
  • Make sure staff know emergency procedures

After the event

  • Remove all equipment, structures and waste immediately
  • Return the site to how it was before
  • Tell us about any damage or incidents
  • Pay electricity costs if you used council electricity

Staffing and security

General rule You should have at least 1 event staff member for every 100 people attending. For example, if you expect 475 people, you need at least 5 staff members.

You will need:

  • Marshals at road closure points, emergency exits, and crowd control areas
  • Security for larger events or where alcohol is served
  • Staff who understand emergency procedures, evacuation routes, and first aid provision

Safeguarding: All staff and volunteers working with children must have appropriate checks, including DBS checks where required.

Facilities you must provide

Toilets

You must provide enough toilets based on how many people will attend and how long your event lasts. You must provide accessible toilets.

General rule: 1 toilet for every 100-150 people. More if you are serving alcohol.

First aid

You must provide first aid based on your event size and risks:

  • Small events – first aid kit and trained first aider
  • Larger events – first aid point, multiple trained first aiders, consider St John Ambulance

Waste management

You must provide:

  • Enough bins
  • Litter collection during the event
  • Site clearance after the event
  • Separate waste streams for recycling if possible

Electricity

If you need electricity:

  • It must be installed by a qualified electrician
  • Check with City Events team if council electricity supply is available
  • If using generators, include them in your risk assessment and site plan
  • You will be charged for electricity usage after the event

What is not allowed

These items are not permitted at events:

  • Sky lanterns and balloon releases
  • Bonfires on parks or verges
  • Metal detecting without permission
  • Fireworks without specific approval
  • Animals for entertainment (performing animals, animals in costumes, animal rides)
  • Hazardous materials

Who can apply

Anyone can apply, including:

  • Individuals
  • Community groups
  • Charities
  • Commercial organisations

We cannot approve events that:

  • Are for political parties
  • Promote hatred or discrimination
  • Would cause unreasonable disruption
  • Cannot be made safe

Costs

There is a fee to use council land for events. The amount depends on:

  • Which venue or park you choose
  • How long your event lasts
  • What type of event (community or commercial)
  • How many people will attend
  • What facilities you need

We may also ask for a damage deposit to protect against damage to the site. This will be refunded if you return the site in good condition.

Payment is due before your event.

Our service standards

  • We will reply to your first contact within 5 working days
  • We will decide on your application within 4 weeks of receiving all documents
  • Larger events may take longer if they need Safety Advisory Group approval
  • City Events Manager is available for advice before you apply
  • We will offer a site visit if needed
  • Emergency contact is available on event day

Start your application

Contact the City Events team to discuss your event plans before applying.
